results.title: Beefcake
results.creator_credit: Thom Fitzgerald, Shandi Mitchell, Channel 4 TV and Alliance Independent Films
results.brief_description: Based on the life of photographer Bob Mizer who photographed young men for male physique magazines, this is an entertaining combination of fiction and documentary which examines the underground gay culture of America in the 1950s. Centred around Mizer’s trial for obscenity during the McCarthy witch-hunts, “Beefcake” features interviews with models, hustlers and muscle builders from that period as well as creating a fictional narrative about young Neil O’Hara (Joe Pearce), the traditional All-American small-town boy, who arrives in the big city of Los Angeles and becomes immersed in the world of muscles, photography and the incipient gay movement. Filmed in glorious colour which simulates the rainbow palette of the “technicolor fifties”, “Beefcake” is nevertheless a highly insightful look into the cost of repression. The film acknowledges the complexity of Mizer’s relationship with the young men he photographed, as well as his initially tender but ultimately destructive relationship with his mother, who encouraged his work but refused the evidence of his sexuality. And though “Beefcake” suggests that Mizer’s world allowed young gay men freedom for the first time in their lives, it also examines how Mizer himself was blind to the effects of drugs and loneliness on his young subjects. The interviewees include Warhol superstar Joe Dellasandro who began his career as a Physique magazine model.

results.title: Pharaoh = Faraon [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jerzy Kawalerowicz, Ludwik Hager, Film Polski, WFF Lodz and ZRF Kadr
results.brief_description: An epic costume drama set in ancient Egyptian times during the reign of Pharaoh Ramses XIII (Jerzy Zelnik), who, in defiance of tradition, assumed command of the military - a post usually occupied by priests. The story tells of the battle which consequently ensued between Ramses and his followers and the power driven priests. Based on the novel by Boleslaw Prus and starring Wieslaw Mazurkiewicz, Barbara Brylska, Krystyna Mikolajewska, Ewa Krzyzanowska, Jerzy Buczacki, Leszek Herdegen. Photography by Jerzy Wojcik. (Awards: Nominated for Best Foreign Language Film in 1967 Oscars and Golden Palm in 1966 Cannes Film Festival) NOTE: Colour appears to be faded.

results.title: Austeria = The Inn [NTSC]
results.brief_description: A psychological drama set during World War 1. A group of Jewish civilians living in Polish Galicia flee from the Cossacks and become trapped in a tiny inn. As time passes, fear gives way and relationships between both the civilians and the inn keepers family develop, whilst still fearing that they will be discovered at any moment. This film won the Golden Lion award at the Gdynia Polish Film Festival. In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: The Deluge = Potop. Parts 1 and 2 [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jerzy Hoffman, Wilhelm Hollender and Film Polski
results.brief_description: This is a film of epic proportions somewhat reminiscent to “Doctor Zhivago” in its grandness, its breathtaking scenery, superb cinematography (Jerzy Wojcik), evocative images and a fine cast of actors. Based on the Nobel prize-winning novel by author Henryk Sienkiewicz, “The Deluge” takes place in 17th century Poland, during the Polish-Swedish War (1655-1660) with the central plot revolving around the intense and often stormy love affair between the main character, Andrzej Kmicic (Daniel Olbrychski), a noble man and a soldier often erratic in temperament, and Olenka (Malgorzata Braunek) a young gentlewoman of strong beliefs and convictions who will over the course of their relationship, be forced to question the morality of the war and Andrzej’s involvement in it. Shot on location in Poland in many of the ancient and historic castles and accompanied by an original muscial score (by Kazimierz Serocki) which enhances and adds depth to the story, this is a war film with a difference. The myriad of characters representing all walks of life, from the peasants to the aristocracy, through to the soldiers in battle, weave in and out of the story adding a sense of realism and involvement for the onlooker. “Potop” was nominated for Best Foreign Film in the 1974 Academy Awards. Cast also includes Tadeusz Lomnicki, Kazimierz Wichniarz, Wladyslaw Hancza, Leszek Teleszynski. WARNING: The English subtitles are often out of sync, and sometimes too fast to read.

results.title: My crazy life = Mi vida loca
results.creator_credit: Allison Anders, Carl-Jan Colpaert, Daniel Hassid and Cineville
results.brief_description: Echo Park is a tough inner city neighbourhood, made up of mainly Hispanic-Americans. Violence, drugs and gangs are part of life here but instead of focusing on the male violence, Allison Anders has centred the narrative around the phenomenon of girl gangs, love and hate, friendship and rivalry as they struggle to fight for their own identity within the gang regime. Sad Girl (Angel Aviles), Mousie (Seidy Lopez) and Ernesto (Jacob Vargas) are the central characters which the film revolves around and the romantic entanglements between Ernesto and Sad Girl and Ernesto and Mousie - whilst initially causing havoc and betrayal - finally unites the three together. There is an underlying feminist feel to this film which includes several other female characters providing narration, depth and a richness to the central theme. Actual gang members were used along with several cameo roles by film directors, musicians and the members of Los Lobos. Cast also includes Panchito Gomez, Julian Reyes, Marlo Marron, Bertila Damas, Ric Salinas, Salma Hayek, Christina Solis, Gabriel Gonzales, Arthur Esquer, Nelida Lopez and Jesse Borrego.

results.title: The Red violin = Le Violon rouge = Violino rosso, Il
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman, Mikado Film Srl (Rome), Sidecar Films and TV and Red Violin Productions
results.brief_description: A five part tale which tells the life story of an exquisite 300 year old violin. The film begins with the loving creation of the instrument in 17th century in Italy by a master craftsman for his unborn child. However, upon the death of the baby the instrument maker curses the violin by adding a secret ingredient to the varnish. The central focus is at an auction house in Montreal where the legendary violin is for sale and the bidding is fierce. The focus of the film is not so much the violin’s future, but its affect on the five lives of those who played it over the years, as we are drawn back into each of their worlds. Coveted by child prodigies, virtuosos and gypsies, the instrument is a poisoned chalice with most of the people who play it meeting a tragic and untimely end. This ambitious film is shot in Cremona, Vienna, Oxford, Shanghai and Montreal, with dialogue in French, English, Italian, Spanish and Mandarin. An Academy Award winning musical soundtrack composed by John Corigliano reminds us of the beauty of the violin as the viewer follows its travels across time and space. Written by Don McKellar and Francois Girard.

results.title: The Woodlanders
results.creator_credit: Phil Agland, Barney Reisz, Pathe Productions and Channel Four
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Thomas Hardy, “The Woodlanders” is a passionate story of love. Giles Winterborne (Rufus Sewell) and Grace Melbury (Emily Woof) have had an agreement to marry since childhood. However, Grace’s return from boarding school and subsequent elevation in society cause their engagement to be called off. Silently adored by his friend, Marty, Giles continues to pine for Grace, whilst she in turn falls in love with the handsome new doctor, Fitzpiers. But as they follow their separate courses, Grace and Giles find that their lives become inextricably entwined.

results.title: The Quiet man
results.creator_credit: John Ford and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Set in Ireland in the 1820s, this is the story of Irish-born American Sean Thornton (John Wayne) who, after a long and profitable career as a boxer, returns home to settle down and forget a tragic accident in the boxing ring which killed his opponent. Sean buys back his ancestral home, Thornton Cottage, much to the disgust of the neighbouring squire, Red Will Danaher (Victor McLagen). To further complicate matters, Sean has fallen in love with Red Will’s sister, Mary Kate (Maureen O’Hara). Sean must battle against all manner of Irish blarney to get the hand of the girl he loves. This amusing romantic comedy was a change of pace for John Wayne (and John Ford) at the time, although the movie is usually remembered for the fight scene between the characters of O’Hara and Wayne which culminates in him dragging her across a field followed by the entire village.

results.title: The Whistle blower
results.creator_credit: Simon Langton, Geoffrey Reeve and Portreeve
results.brief_description: Nigel Havers plays a Russian linguist employed by an English spy centre to intercept and interpret KGB phone conversations. His father, portrayed by Michael Caine, is a conservative businessman and former intelligence officer whose faith in England is shattered after he uncovers the intricate web of deceit and cover-up employed by his country’s secret services. Following leads left by his son, he sets out to investigate the tactics and activities of the intelligence networks and the identity of the people they protect. Also stars James Fox, Felicity Deans, Sir John Gielgud, Kenneth Colley, Gordon Jackson, David Langton and Barry Foster. Screenplay by Julian Bond, based on the novel by John Hale. Photography by Fred Tammes. Edited by Robert Morgan. Music composed and conducted by John Scott, performed by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

results.title: Solomon and Gaenor
results.creator_credit: Paul Morrison, Sheryl Crown, APT Film and Television and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description: Set against the Tredegar riots against Jewish shops in 1911, “Solomon and Gaenor” is a tragic love story of Jewish cloth merchant, Solomon (Ioan Gruffudd), and Gaenor (Nia Roberts), daughter of a struggling Welsh mining family. Solomon keeps his Jewish heritage a secret from his new love, who becomes frustrated by his inability to settle down and marry, and for the unspoken secrets between them. They are forced to re-evaluate their relationship when Gaenor falls pregnant and tensions mount between striking Welsh miners and Jewish storeholders, placing Solomon’s family in the front line. Director Paul Morrison asserts that the film is principally about the universal notion that we hide aspects of ourselves from those we love. He also manages to capture a painful chapter in the British Jewish experience. Cast also includes Sue Jones Davies, William Thomas and Mark Jones. In Welsh, Hebrew and English with English subtitles.

results.description: Set against the Tredegar riots against Jewish shops in 1911, “Solomon and Gaenor” is a tragic love story of Jewish cloth merchant, Solomon (Ioan Gruffudd), and Gaenor (Nia Roberts), daughter of a struggling Welsh mining family. Solomon keeps his Jewish heritage a secret from his new love, who becomes frustrated by his inability to settle down and marry, and for the unspoken secrets between them. They are forced to re-evaluate their relationship when Gaenor falls pregnant and tensions mount between striking Welsh miners and Jewish storeholders, placing Solomon’s family in the front line. Director Paul Morrison asserts that the film is principally about the universal notion that we hide aspects of ourselves from those we love. He also manages to capture a painful chapter in the British Jewish experience. Cast also includes Sue Jones Davies, William Thomas and Mark Jones. In Welsh, Hebrew and English with English subtitles.
